PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: MARY EDITH ALICIA KAJEWSKI

2. Your address: Box 189, CRAIK, SASK.

3. Date: April 9th, 1963

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): In Warkentin - Ontario - Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Harold Kowor - Owner and builder of Flour Mills

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): Jan. 1899

7. Mention any other places where you have lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

   - Parkville, Manitoba: 1886 to 1889
   - Red River, Manitoba: 1889 to 1897
   - Brandon, Manitoba: 1897 to 1899

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.). Three years.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? My father came in 1885 and built flour mill in Crest Rasko. We had to move up by Red River Road in 1879 because land to homestead out shipped source. The first Red River settlement heard wheat hard times mill.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other Railroad or government information?). Reading about it!
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

When we went to Bambin (Ariana) on our way through we were going to the North Pole!

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Came out from Ontario with mother and baby sister and mother's brother, H.S.R. Macintosh.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train and car to Brandon and not sure if we drove or came by train to Red River.

14. That incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way etc.)

Seeing my first negro on train was I believe an event in my young life, and personally knew my corn cob today more years on it's arrival on the boat and I remember of Ontario's own big dinosaurs by a Mr. Gorley and big doe givers to me by a Mr. Gorley when learning.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

My mother had arrived home in Quappelle while putting old MacMillan Bros. mind in while putting over what I returned had.

16. Where did you settle or take up land in?

Age 6-1947 - Quappelle

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Quappelle 1899-1909 and 1910-1930

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Daughter school manitoba 1901 -
McKean-Sask. 1902-1904 -
Bookkeeping Mira Milling Co. 1904-1909

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Regularly and often.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Dec. 10, 1895 to Mr. William J. Smith.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, to settle?

Yes, several of my sisters came to Saskatchewan because of my recommendation.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Sons of Joseph and Mary Smith (my parents) came to Saskatchewan in 1896.

23. Is there any particular experiences of pioneer days that stand out in your mind?

Yes, the first winter was very hard. We had to build our own shelter.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

Yes, I traveled quite a bit. I went to Brandon by train and visited Winnipeg by train.

25. What was the most important event in your life?

The birth of my children.
